column11: Review Text
Spectacular views and peaceful temple awaits at this beauty spot, not too challenging to walk and easy terrain to walk on. Well worth the short hike. Would recommend

It is worth the climb if you have the time available, the view from the top is pretty (although we did not see the single tree). Easy walk to the top, especially if you are transported to the temple. Took us about 20-25 mins with a 10 & 7 year old
One of the easiest treck in nuwara, this starts from a temple and you reach to top in 20 min is you are on right path. Amazing view of lake from top
This is comparatively easiest treck in nuwara eliya. There is temple and walk of 25 mins to top of the hill which offers great view of city and lake
This is one of the mountains among 10th highest list. On the way you can worship the  temple and there is a another beautiful view there. On the top you can see whole Nuwaraeliya town and suburbs.

The walk is lovely, but don't do it alone, particularly if you are female. Whilst I was walking up Single Tree Hill in May 2018, I met two policemen who stopped me and said to be careful as there had been an attack and they had still not caught the person. Please note: I have posted this review of my personal experience of Single Tree more than once - I live in Nuwara Eliya and walk here most weeks and it has not been posted any of the times - I don't know why

We started at the temple (got 4 min drive up) and from there it's a nice easy 20 min stroll up to the top. Nice scenic views along the way, overlooking much of the area. View at the top is pretty much the same as the view along the way. Didn't manage to identify any "single tree" :) recommended!

This was my first full day in Nuwara Eliya so i left my guest house after breakfast, and reached the turn-off by the SW corner of the race track by 9 am and started the climb up the road to the top of the hill. I think it was about 4 kms through a tea estate and eventually the road turned into a track before reaching several communication towers. Then there was a path that led me around the fenced compounds which eventually led to the "Single Tree", but i guess there were at least three trees there now, surrounded by tea trees. The single tree was easy to recognise as there were orange scarves tied to the tree and a few figures at the base, which served as a shrine. From this vantage point there was a wonderful view of the town, racetrack, Gregory Lake and surrounding hills and it was well worth spending 15 minutes up here. There seemed to be another path leading back to the small road, but after a while i had to retrace my steps as it became impossible to follow.

We drove up to the temple and from there you can get good views of the countryside, Eliya and the tea plantations. We did not walk to the top as with the intermittent rain I doubt we could have gotten a better view.  this site is purely a viewpoint and nothing else. There is nothing else around!

This is one of the best location to view the Nuwara Eliya. The road is sealed up to the Single Tree Hill monastery.You could take a taxi or hire car up to the monastery & park there. Past the monastery, it is all gravel road, would not recommend taking a car unless it is 4x4. The walk from the monastery is about 20 mins. On the top of the hill is a telecom tower. Towards the end of the walk, you will come across wired fences, go past the fence & you will be able to get spectacular views of Nuwara Eliya, the lake, mountains and tea fields.

It was just after some rain had cleared so the too was shrouded in mist but I went up anyway. The road first winds gently through tea fields and past a temple then becomes a steeper, rougher road. Shortly before the top, you can see a small blue shrine above on the right. Look for some rough stairs and you can follow these to a bench in front of the towers. Didn’t help me that day as I couldn’t see anything from the top but from lower down the road I spectacular views of southern Nuwara Eliya, the lake, mountains and tea fields.

To start the walk head out of town, at roundabout take Badulla Road then watch out for Single Tree Road on the right after 800m. From there it's simple - the road snakes up through a tea plantation, past a temple and towards the masts. Once you get to the masts there's a narrow track between two fences that takes you to the view over to Gregory Lake. There's a seat to have a rest. From there we headed back to the main track, then continued along the crest of the hill on a narrow track, which eventually drops at some huts. We cut right here and joined Unique View Road back down the hill, with a beer stop at Qantara Hotel, which has a terrace with a view! Nice to do the loop rather than up and down. Even saw monkeys along the crest walk.

This is a pleasant easy walk to the top of a hill overlooking Nuwara Eliya.  Although it ranks as one of the highest mountains in Sri Lanka, it is only about an hour's steady walk from the town through tea plantations.  Keep a look out for Barking Deer.  The single tree has long since gone and has been replaced by telecommunications masts, but with your back to them, you have great views.  Unlike Horton Plains and World's End, it is free!

The trek to Single Tree Hill is not challenging and is quite picturesque, giving you views of the city as you walk along tea plantations for some time. The entry point is a small lane right beside Cliffton Hotel. The final point is reached by taking stairs to the right where the Google Maps path ends. Although the summit isn't as amazing as you would think, the trek is worth doing.

The most challenging part was finding the entry point to Single Tree Hill Road. It is off Queen Elizabeth Road, about 50 from Haddon Hill Road, and next to Clifton Inn. Once you are on that road, there can be no mistake about how to proceed. The road starts as a narrow asphalt road winding itself up to a beautiful monastery, about half way to the top. It continues as a narrow dirt road which can be driven with a high clearance vehicle or tuk-tuk.  Unfortunately there is a lot of trash dumping along the way. We walked up and down, which took about 45 minutes each way, with plenty of stops for taking in the marvelous views of the tea landscape below us. There is no need to walk to the very end, as bushes obstruct the view in that section.
This is a little of the beaten track, but it's a great little walk up a hill between the tea fields. We took a shortcut down towards the tea fields.

This is a two hours long walk (there and back) through a hilly tea field in Nuwara Eliya that provides great views over the town and surrounding tea plantations. I really enjoyed it. It was a bit hard to find the path though (yes, there is one!). Go along the Queen Elisabeth road, then turn right to the Haddon Hill road all the way to Teabush hotel, where the road end. The Teabush is fenced and you need to go around the fenced area from its right side. There is a narrow slippery path. It is disappearing at times, but try to keep following it, it zig-zags all the way to the top. If you lose sight of it, just go up among the bushes (thats what I did half of the way as I didnt know about the path) - you will eventually come across it again. Wouldnt recommend this walk with children, but its a nice outing if you have a few hours to kill. The view is brilliant.

The view of the city and of the surrounding hills was amazing. It is a long but not difficult hike to reach the top. Sometimes the mist can cover the view but I was lucky that day because it faded quickly. On the way to the top there is also a small temple

Best place to get a whole view of Nuwara Eliya. You can enjoy a quick hike through tea bushes and a bit of a jungle. The views along the hike a incredible and on a clear morning, you are able to see the top of Adam's Peak, just as you pass the temple (Picture is attached here). This hike was what I enjoyed most about my visit to Nuwara Eliya. Definite must do if you're visiting Nuwara Eliya.

At the top, there is a temple. You can have some great views of Nuwara-Eliya city from here. If you are not coming by a private vehicle, there is a bit of climbing to do. The road to the top is not at the best condition. But, it should be manageable, even it is somewhat narrow. Parking is also available in the temple.

It was a bit difficult to find the starting point when we walked from the centre of the town. We passed a tourist information close to the bus station, but the "map" they offered was not very specific. The hike goes through tea plantations and is quite easy, but steeper when you approach the top of the hill. Nice view from the top (2100 all) until it started to rain. It seems to be optional paths to get down, but since they were not marked, we decided to return the way we came.

I thoroughly enjoyed the walk up Single Tree Hill this week. However on the way back down just above the temple, I was attacked by a local man with a knife wanting to rape me. I was in hiking gear - trousers, boots, Tshirt, rucksack so nothing provocative. Fortunately I practice martial arts, so was confident and able to diffuse the situation without any physical violence. It could have been a very different story. Single women - seriously reconsider doing this walk alone.
Quite a fast (1h30 at most) walk in the middle of the tea plantations, with a fantastic view on Nuwara Eliya and its surroundings. Easy and enjoyable !

Wonderful quiet walk taking no more than 2 hours return. Small entrance road to start walk opposite town end of racecourse. Beautiful Buddhist temple not far from the top which is worth a visit. Very good road/path the whole way to the summit around 7000ft. Fenced off TV masts at summit. Altogether one of the nicest things to do in Nuwara Eliya for a bit of exercise.

Like a previous reviewer said, this place is not well signposted. We weren't staying nearby and we had to ask for directions. No one seemed to know where this elusive hill was. We finally found Single Tree Road, which is also known as Scur State Road on Google maps. The entrance is right in front of the Nuwara Eliya Race Course grounds. Once we established we were on the right track, it was an easy walk up to the top, through a tea plantation. We brought sandwiches and had a picnic brunch with an amazing view. The kids found it fun.

You can see nuwaraeliya town very nicely from this mountain. There is a telecommunication tower top of the mountain. So no enterence for that area.but can see from other side.  you can see best scenario of gregory lake from this mountain. There is a road (you can go by vehicle) until top of mountain towards telecommunication tower. Very nice and cold place.
Not very well sign posted. We ended up climbing like goat through the tea plantation and found an easier way down through a little  Tamil village.  Great views.

This is the best place to see all Nuwaraeliya. Scenic view is almost feel like in the sky. There is no place like this. Nice route to Single Tree Hill through a healthy tea plantation. Cool climate makes the trip even better.

the view is absolutely breath taking. Many people hike there - however, we took the easy way out and took a cab. the road is pretty narrow - not a problem if you are gonna hike though. Once you reach the point, you can see the city spread around you, tea gardens etc.

Hike lasts max 2 hours, starting from the Single Tree Road (who would have guessed). The road almost has no traffic, it's quiet. We did this after we visited Adams Peak the day before, and the hike was still doable. Funny is that you can see Adams Peak from the top,so if you're planning to go to Adams Peak or you just went there, it's nice to see it from another place as well. Underway you can visit a Buddha temple if you like. We didn't enter, but it looked good from the outside. On top you can see the lake, the horse track and various other things in town. Just take the small path on the right between the antennas and enjoy the view! A little bit further there is a small path to the left through some small trees. You'll end up in a tree plantation and can go through it to go down the hill. It's a nice path but with hindsight I would rather start in the tea plantation and then go downwards via the road, which is easier. Nice to do if you've got some hours left to do something!

This is the 9th highest peak of Sri Lanka. If you wants to go you have to travel from Nuwaraeliya city towards Badulla rd and you will find a small road towards Single tree hill after about 2,km. You have motorable road up to the top but it's fun and nice to hike. You are not allow to go to the top as there are some telecommunications towers. Once you go up it's fabulous view over Nuwaraeliya city, Gregory lake . You can take some beautiful pictures So If you come to Nuwaraeliya don't miss Single tree hill

When we arrived there, it's raining and cold. We decided to stay in but when it's clear we went out and finding a free places to visit, a tuk tuk driver told us about this place, we love it. Only one place its free to visit and you have to go!.

Nice and easy trekking that takes no more than two hours return. It is quite a lonely way and we did it in a misty afternoon. At the summit there is no single tree but TV antennas instead, but doesn't matter, it is worth doing it as an alternative plan in a small town.
